awd_abstract_narration:
The funding will support early-stage researchers (students, post docs and junior faculty) to attend the Fluidization XVII conference (May 21-25, 2023, Edinburgh, Scotland). Attendance at the conference will ensure continued U.S. competitiveness in the fundamental research and emerging applications of fluidization for novel fluidization technologies field. Over the past few decades, notable advances in the fundamental understanding of fluidized systems have been possible via a combination of careful experiments, simulations, and theory. Nonetheless, the understanding and accurate prediction of fluidized system is nowhere near its single-phase counterparts, in which software like computational fluid dynamics (CFD) solvers provide a reliable tool for design and scale-up. 

The objectives of this proposed effort include: (i) bringing together members of industry, academia and national laboratories to showcase different perspectives and approaches, as well as to encourage potential collaborations; (ii) encouraging active participation by graduate researchers and post docs who represent the future of the field; (iii) bringing scientists and engineers together to provide an inviting and inclusive atmosphere to openly discuss their disciplines and approaches, thereby motivating new collaborations and new lines of inquiry;, (iv) going beyond the technical content associated with new research, and bringing to the foreground content related to education, professional development, and diversity and inclusion; and (v) particular outreach to underrepresented groups in STEM at all levels – conference organizing committees, invited speakers, and participants. The NSF support will be provided to emerging scientists (students, postdocs, and junior faculty) and underrepresented groups to ensure a diverse audience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
Conference: Fluidization XVII Conference Support

Project Outcomes Report
Award 2315967

The 2023 Fluidization Conference took place May 21-25 at the Sheraton Grand Hotel and Spa in Edinburgh, Scotland. The conference brought together early-career and world-expert researchers and industrial practitioners from around the globe to discuss new developments in fundamental research and progress in industrial applications. Gathering 171 attendees Fluidization covered a wide array of topics within the field, including:

  • Applications
    • Design & Operability
    • Circular Economy
      • Waste
      • Carbon Capture & Vectors
  • Process Intensification
  • Energy Storage & Carriers
  • Biomass & Bioenergy
  • Fundamentals
    • Fluctuating Motions
    • Bubbling, Mixing & Segregation
    • AI Tools
    • Transport Phenomena
    • Measurements
    • Modelling
      • Circulating Fluidized Beds
      • Systems Modelling
      • The Role of Particle Size & Shape
      • Heat & Mass Transfer
      • Manufacturing
      • Large Scale Modelling
      • Coarse Grained Simulations
      • Particle Resolved Simulations

Over the course of the 5 day conference, world leading researchers presented on cutting-edge developments over the past three years. Over 70 oral presentations and panels took place during the conference. Additionally, over 60 trainees and early career professionals presented their work during the poster sessions. Breaks, lunches, receptions and other networking sessions throughout the meeting provided opportunities for attendees to connect in a more informal setting, exchanging ideas for future collaborations and discussion career development opportunities.

A Social Values panel featured a discussion between panelists and attendees about underrepresentation in STEM fields and implicit bias. In addition to this panel, social values talks throughout the program helped to build a stronger, more diverse and inclusive fluidization community.

Keynote speakers represented a wide range of backgrounds and expertise areas, highlighting breakthrough developments and inspiring future leaders in fluidization. Keynote speakers included:

  • Joan Cordiner, University of Sheffield
  • Karl Jacob, University of Michigan
  • Piero Salatino, University of Naples Federico II
  • Takuya Tsuji, Osaka University

Funds from the NSF were used to provide registration support for students, post-docs and early career faculty at U.S.-based universities. This support allowed trainees and early career faculty, who often face financial limitations in attending conferences, the ability to gain valuable knowledge, connection and development opportunities.

 


Last Modified: 08/07/2024
Modified by: Evan Flach
